column4: Hello, using kubuntu, I want to connect to the wireless network on the campus. From windows vista (in which it was fairly easy to connect), I gathered that I need to set the settings to use WEP encryption with PEAP and EAP-MSCHAP v2. When I, in the kde network manager set it to web, I can't choose PEAP tho, then I can choose MSCHAPv2, and fill in username and password
But when I do this, it just doesn't connect and the dialog pops up again. So how can I connect to the wireless network?
I mean, with WPA-EAP I can choose MSCHAP.
I have no idea what it all means, just that it doesn't work :((
It keeps saying "Connection failed". And I have less luck with the gtk network settings manager
So how do you guys connect to wireless networks with username and password?
Why can't the settings manager detect the settings of the network?
Seems like everyone has trouble with wireless networks
are you using NetworkManager ?
yes
and the Network Management applet
is the access point you're wanting to connect to showing up as an SSID in your pulldown ?
the SSID field doesn't have a pulldown, but it autodetected WLAN (which is the name of the access point)
some routers are "weird" about how they cache credentials ... you may need to delete any settings you've made and try again
ah, I see
what do I fill in for 'Anonymous identify'?
does your accesspoint use encryption? IE WPA?
WPA-EAP
or at least, it uses PEAP and MSCHAPv2, which I can only choose when selecting WPA-EAP
vista said the network used WEP, tho
can you set it to WPA(1 or 2) home + TKIP ?
I can only choose WPA-PSK and WPA-EAP in the dropdown box
also, do I need 'Infrastructure' or 'ad hoc' for Mode?
right, you want infrastructure, but on the router itself can you set it to use WPA Personal TKIP ?
in my experience the encryption is "good enough" and it configures across the board for all wifi devices
ah, the router itself. I have no control over the router, unfortunately. It's provided by the campus
do you have some kind of academic computer services a try?
well, I got it to work on the same laptop on windows vista
(I think that was your question, I didn't fully understand it)
no doubt, but there may be some kind of secondary verification layer.  Many higher education wifi networks have some sort of scanning tool that may just automatically run in Vista
I see, so what can I do?
contact your campus technical support would be the best step
oh I see. I'll try that then, thanks a lot for the help
I don't think the problem is your wireless card or ubuntu
I guess, but it's so weird, in vista you only have to provide username and password, in linux you have to fill in everything manually and it just refuses to work
I know ... your tech support should have alternative configuration settings for both Mac and Linux
sometimes I just get annoyed with all this. For instance, I have an intel graphics card, and the drivers don't support screens bigger than 2048x2048, so you can say goodbye to dual screen
and then there's the fact that kaffeine, xine, mplayer, and any video player except vlc segfault *the whole X server* sometimes
I run my netbook with one monitor at 1200x600 and the other at 1920x1080 and it has an intel graphics chipset
all on one intel card?
yup, with an atom processor none-the-less
there are many intel cards with different drivers I believe, but mine isn't supported for that
it's a "known bug" that just doesn't get fixed
I'm using a pretty old 945 set
ah. I wish I had an nvidia, the closed drivers just always worked for me :)
